Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Structure and Dynamical Mechanisms of Membrane Transport Proteins: New Vistas Via Ultra-stable Force Microscopy

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
In order for a cell to operate properly, some proteins must pass through membranes while other proteins must fold and insert themselves into membranes. How are these complex processes achieved at the molecular scale? What are the forces involved? How long does it take for the proteins to rearrange themselves? This research project aims to shed light on these issues by directly observing the arrangements and motions of individual proteins as they negotiate membranes. Techniques that are traditionally used in cellular studies have inherent challenges. As a result, there is little detailed knowledge regarding the complex molecular motions associated with these critical biological processes. The PI has developed and will employ a new tool- an ultra-high precision microscope- to directly study these interactions. This unique instrument, which is based on force, offers the potential to achieve atomically precise measurements of proteins and membranes in their natural state (in water at room temperature). These measurements, in conjunction with computer modeling and traditional biochemical experiments, will elucidate fundamental aspects of protein secretion and membrane protein folding.

Broader Impacts
The interface of molecular biology, nanotechnology and precision measurement provides a rich interdisciplinary medium that will broadly enhance the impact of this project. The educational and outreach activities of this project aim to address pressing needs across the educational spectrum, from elementary through graduate school to adult learning. These activities include: writing science education curriculum for a teacher training program aimed at improving elementary education in the state of Missouri; continued mentoring of high school and undergraduate students; creating incentives and training mechanisms to increase the impact of graduate student outreach activities; and entering direct dialogue with general audiences through interactive public speaking commitments. Collectively, these educational and outreach activities are designed to reach a broad range of individuals of all ages and backgrounds. Their overall objective is to promote scientific literacy and to convey the excitement of performing cutting edge scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological membranes consist chiefly of a mixture of proteins and lipids. Despite the extreme importance of membrane interfaces in biology, very little is known about the mechanisms of how these essential cellular components interact. In order for a cell to operate properly, some proteins must pass through membranes while other proteins must fold and insert themselves into the lipid bilayer. How are these complex processes achieved at the molecular scale? What are the forces involved? How long does it take for the proteins to rearrange themselves? This research project shed light on these issues by directly observing the arrangements and motions of individual proteins as they negotiated membrane interfaces. Techniques that are traditionally used in cellular studies have inherent challenges when interrogating membranes. As a result, there is little detailed knowledge regarding the complex molecular motions associated with these critical biological processes.

The PI’s laboratory developed and applied new instrumentation, including an ultra-high precision microscope, to directly study interactions at the single-molecule level. This unique instrument, which is based on measurement of force, achieved precise measurements of proteins and membranes in their natural state (in water at room temperature). We also developed a single-molecule peptide-lipid bilayer affinity assay, extended the supporting surfaces available for high resolution membrane protein force microscope imaging, established a novel observable for atomic force microscopy that facilitates direct access to the three-dimensional tip-sample interaction, and achieved routine, extremely sensitive (sub-pN) force precision for biological force microscopy. Application of these methods, in conjunction with analytical and computer modeling, as well as traditional biochemical experiments, elucidated fundamental aspects of protein secretion and membrane protein folding.

Specifically, we performed the first force microscope imaging of SecYEG, the ubiquitous protein conducting channel from E. coli. Imaging individual SecYEG translocons in lipid bilayers at physiologically relevant temperature and ionic strength revealed the oligomeric state of this critical membrane protein as well as significant conformational dynamics that underlie protein function. Further, we developed a highly active in vitro reconstitution system which enabled us to address longstanding questions in the field. For example, we assigned a role for the membrane-associated SecA enzyme – to activate SecYEG – and showed that the oligomeric state of the translocon varies with the specific species of precursor protein being transported. Finally, by directly measuring the interaction force between proteins (including segments of SecA) and lipids we were able to reconstruct the complex energy landscapes that dictate how proteins and membranes interact at the molecular scale.

The scientific results of this project have been disseminated widely via peer-reviewed publications, scientific meeting, and news outlets. Additionally, the work received recognition for innovation from the microscopy community and a U.S. Patent has been issued to facilitate commercialization.

In terms of broader impacts, the interface of molecular biology, nanotechnology and precision measurement apparatus in the PI’s laboratory provided a rich interdisciplinary medium that enhanced the impact of this project. The educational and outreach activities addressed pressing needs across the educational spectrum, from kindergarten through graduate school to adult learning. Specifically, these activities included a new graduate-level course “Biophysics Education Outreach” which led to the development of five research-based interdisciplinary curriculum supplements aligned to K-12 Grade Level Expectations (Missouri state standards). These supplements focused on “The Biophysics of the Human Body” and were piloted to a cohort of middle school students at a week-long summer camp co-organized by the PI. The supplements were then revised based on teacher feedback and disseminated via the internet. Additionally, the PI developed a new course “Single Molecule Biophysics” (cross-listed in both Physics and Biochemistry). Other activities included: organizing a kindergarten lesson on magnification in the laboratory, judging at a school science fair and several undergraduate research forms, leading a workshop at the Science Teachers of Missouri Conference, talking to in-service teachers at the Quality Elementary School Teaching workshop, and giving a public lecture ‘What does it take to pick up a molecule?’. Graduate students in PI’s lab participated in “Missouri Adventures in Education,” and were recognized with the “Chancellor’s Award in Public Outreach.”  Seven graduate students received training in the PI’s laboratory (four of whom are female, one African American). Six undergraduate students received training (three female, one African American, one disabled); the five who have already graduated have all gone on to graduate school. Additionally, the PI hosted a female high school student as well as a high school science teacher for summer research in the laboratory. Collectively, these educational and outreach activities reached a broad range of individuals of many ages and backgrounds.
